awd_titl_txt: Signaling mechanisms that regulate attractive axon guidance at the CNS midline
awd_abstract_narration:
The establishment of proper neuron connections during development is essential for coordinated behavior.  Axons, the wires of the nervous system, are guided to their targets by attractive and repulsive cues.  This project will investigate the mechanisms that promote axon attraction to the midline of the fly central nervous system.  Similar to the vertebrate floor plate, the fly midline is an intermediate target for navigating axons, which must decide whether or not to cross the midline.  Netrin attracts axons to the midline through receptors of the Deleted in Colorectal Carcinoma (DCC) family (frazzled in Drosophila).  However, it is unclear how Frazzled/DCC signaling mediates axon attraction and what additional mechanisms contribute to midline circuit assembly.  Defining these mechanisms will enrich understanding of how guidance molecules work in the intact animal and have the potential to suggest therapeutic targets for disorders of the nervous system.  The project includes outreach activities that are aimed at increasing high school scientific literacy and aptitude.  Each summer, a high school teacher will spend six weeks in the laboratory, where he/she will collaborate with lab personnel to conduct original research and design a teaching module to bring back to the classroom. 

To define mechanisms mediating axon attraction, this proposal seeks 1) to identify genes that act with Fra to control midline guidance, 2) to determine how the novel role of Fra in activating gene transcription is regulated by receptor proteolysis, and 3) to test if nuclear localization and transcriptional activation function of the Fra intracellular domain (ICD) are required for Fra-dependent gene expression.  A sensitized genetic screen will identify new components that act with Fra to promote midline crossing, and molecular genetic approaches will be used to investigate a novel role for Semaphorin1a (identified in our screen) during midline guidance.  Molecular and genetic approaches will be used to test the importance of proteolysis of the Fra receptor.  Candidate genes from the screen will be tested for roles in Fra-dependent transcription. In vitro assays in insect and yeast cells will be used to delimit sequences that are necessary and sufficient for nuclear localization, nuclear export, and transactivation function of the Fra ICD.  Finally, in vivo requirements for these elements will be tested by generating mutated forms of the Fra receptor, expressing them as transgenes, and assaying their ability to promote midline axon attraction and target gene expression.

por.por_cntn:
Overview: Defining how neurons are assembled into functional circuits will provide insights into disorders of the nervous system and may suggest strategies to encourage neuronal repair. Axon guidance is an essential process during circuit assembly and it is controlled by conserved families of ligands and receptors that signal to either attract or repel growing axons. In bilaterally symmetric animals, many axons cross the midline to contribute to circuits that allow coordinated sensory and motor behavior. To cross the midline, axons must respond to attractants, such as Netrin and prevent premature responses to repellents, such as Slit.

Intellectual Merit: The genetic screen undertaken during the award period has identified new roles for a number of genes in contributing to the control of axon guidance at the midline and has resulted in a series of peer-reviewed research publications. We have identified several new molecules that regulate midline crossing, and our studies have enhanced our understanding of normal nervous system development. In addition, we have defined a new and unexpected signaling mechanism that allows specific receptor molecules to act directly to control gene expression. Findings from this award form the foundation for future studies that promise to continue to advance the field of neural development. Furthermore, the studies performed under this award offered important training opportunities for undergraduate students, graduate students and postdoctoral fellows.

Broader Impacts: In addition to the scientific advances resulting from this project, there were also significant benefits to human resources development. In particular, we implemented a high school science outreach program in Philadelphia public schools. Four Philadelphia high school teachers successfully completed 6-week summer research positions. Aside from their experience at the bench, these teachers have developed a robust, but adaptable, three module curricula entitled Flies on Ice; And a Roundabout We Go; and I See You Cuz. During the award period, we have disseminated these experiments in city high schools by offering a summer professional development (PD) workshop and then co-teaching in classrooms all at no cost to the teachers. The first cohort of five teachers began in Summer 2018, with a two-day PD presented by the outreach team, which consisted of Bashaw lab members, two teachers who had interned in the lab, and a partnership with the Pennsylvania Society for Biomedical Research (PSBR). During this workshop, teachers became familiar with the content developed and practiced the science in each of the modules. These curriculum modules were implemented in the class room in the 2018-2019 school year.
